description: From Middle English vesture (noun) and vesturen (verb), from Anglo-Norman, from Old French vesteüre, from Vulgar Latin vestītūra (“clothing”), from Latin vestītus, perfect passive participle of vestiō (“to clothe”), from vestis (“garment”).

entries.meaning: A covering of, or like, clothing.
examples: It pencilled each flower with rich and variegated hues, and threw over its exuberant foliage a vesture of emerald green.

verbs.description: vesture (third-person singular simple present vestures, present participle vesturing, simple past and past participle vestured)
